I for one am very excited about VR. It does bring about challenges however, like motion sickness and the baffling aspect of controling your feet with a joystick, your hands with buttons, and the lack of tactile feed back from your environnement.
I hope that they figure out a way to fix some of these issues, like requiring you to shuffle your feet and knees to move at faster speeds, the integration of motion controls and hand 3d captures and translation into the game world, as well as some way to for directional motion to not make you barf.

I was excited to learn about the VR roller coaster and theme park. I was actually just wondering whether VR could rekindle the interest in the video arcade experience. The heavy demand of the technology puts a lot of boundaries around consumer usage, but it seems like a dedicated VR video arcade with all the required technology (headsets, surround sound, controller analogs, omni-directional treadmills, etc) in a space tailor made for the experience for individual or multiple people, would be ideally suited for the technology. It may be that currents costs are still too prohibitive, but I doubt it'll stay that way for long.

VR has also been a prominent part of the defense industry for a while. Simulators for everything from vehicles to firearms has allowed for more realistic practice at lower cost. The creators of Oculus actually planned to market their device to the US government first before realizing the device could be viably sold on the consumer market.

I have the impression that for the first time VR might actually be at the technological minimum of where it needs to be for proper gaming, but there is some question of whether some of the decisions that have been made in making it accessible have been the best and if VR will yet again prove to be just a trend because it requires a bunch of expensive peripherals that game developers might not feel is worth doing justice to if it only affects the experience of a sub-section of their customers. VR gaming probably needs its own console so that games are made specifically for that kind of experience. (Also, if you make a game for one device, it doesn't necessarily work well with a different VR device, so not all of these new VR devices are going to be compatible with all good VR games.) So all this could still be just another trend that wears out consumer and producer enthusiasm until another 10-20 years or so, and hopefully then people will not only have better, cheaper tech, but one can only hope some of them might have better business sense about it, too.

I recently got to have the VR rollercoaster experience on the superman ride at six flags new england. Part way through an error message appeared and the "camera angle" glitched out so that I was able to the entirety of the avatar that was supposed to be representing my body... which did not have a head, since I was never supposed to be able to SEE the area where the head should be. Every single person on the ride experienced the same glitch because we were all watching the same feed.

Terrible glitching aside, it was still very fun. Seeing Superman "save you" as you are "falling to your death" in the simulation was pretty sweet.

Intel dropping their tick-tock cycle implies that Moore's Law may finally be at an end. Its funny that happened right about the time the VR resurgence happened; the timing was terrible. VR needs smaller, more powerful processors to succeed. The end of Moore's Law will most likely be the death of modern VR.

I'm cautiously optimistic about virtual reality. the problem I see with it is: it's inherently limited to first person perspective and maybe third person perspective games. imagine what a VR Madden would look like; you're in first person perspective of whoever is carrying the ball, if you're on offense but how do you do the defense? and how do you transition from a defensive position, which would probably be the classic top down view to a first person view upon an interception, without drawing the player and make them wonder where is the end zone? Now ask yourself how would do VR with baseball or soccer and you'll see how difficult it would be to do traditional sports games in VR.

What about VR Mario, DOTA, Tetris, or Crusader Kings? would VR help these games in any way? are these games even possible to do in VR?

now you can start seeing the problem from a design perspective and if they can address some of these issues, VR has a hope. if not I'll just be another gimmick peripheral

I have a Vive myself, and enough computer power to run it well. I'm looking forward to some developer coming out with a game that's open world and really, like a proper game but with VR mechanics. Yeah, you can make games like Skyrim and Fallout work in VR via an injector, but I want something built from the ground up with that experience. It won't likely be the case for a few years, as the cost of entry is just too high at the moment. You not only need an expensive headset like a Vive or Rift, but also the processing power to back it up, which isn't cheap.

I think VR is here to stay, the question is whether it becomes mainstream, or remains more niche.

Personally, I want something like the Oasis from Ready Player One (And yes, I know it was basically a means for people to ignore problems in the real world, which was distopian, in favour of a glorious, but ultimately fake life. I still want it. We can have both a better real world and awesome VR world.).

PS VR is gonna be a lot more expensive than PC VR, simply because you need additional processing power for the two screens you're running. There's a reason only above average gaming PC's can run the Oculus and HTC properly. Unless a significant graphical downgrade follows the introduction of VR, I doubt it will take off on this console generation.

Also, PC has a much more suitable environment for early testing and concepts, because of the way larger indie market.

You should have mentioned NASA's use of Microsoft's VR headset to navigate and send commands to the mars Rover. I've seen it in real life - it's amazing.

Home Vr, I think, is a dead end. unless they develop something like .hack// or Sword Art Online, Vr at home will require large and very much safe areas to operate.

Roller coasters and virtual reality arenas like what we saw in the video will be where it will succeed the most.

Augmented reality will, I think, work a lot better at home and has the additional bonus of having practical uses. It can also be used with more traditional means. It CAN supplement, for instance, traditional screens.
That was the Past and Present of Virtual Reality. I was genuinely hoping to hear more speculation and predictions for the Future of VR.
